reviewText:
Rogue Legacy is an amazing platformer.  Controls are tight, tons of loot, a vast array of baddies, and a lot of customization options.

However, there isn't much of a story.  Boss battles are fun, but can be quite challenging.  That's good though, as you can get many hours out of this title because of it's challenge and replay value.  There are a good deal of characters you can pick from, each with their own abilities.  It should be noted, however, that each character usually also has a querk, too.  For instance, some characters play the game up-side-down.  Others are color-blind.  Some have flatulence issues.

So, I HIGHLY reccamend Rogue Legacy.  It's a terrifically fun platformer, which has a great soundtrack, and boasts hours of play time.
Very heavily inspired by Castlevania: Symphony of the Night with a few roguelike elements added to it. A bit on the easy side, but still a lot of fun.

Rogue Legacy is a fantastic game that combines the classic action-platforming style (and look) of Castlevania & Ghosts & Ghouls with a modern compulsion based structure that is as clever and innovative as it is challenging.\n\nThe game is far from easy, designed to be a Rogue-Like" game where upon each death
date:
you have to start over and delve once again into the randomly generated castle.


However
recommended: Cellar Door Games have lightened this hardcore feature in a creative and intelligent way through their Lineage System
hoursPlayed: allowing a sense of advancement and progression in a game fundamentally about perma-death and skill runs.\n\nUpon each death
voteText: you are asked to choose an heir to your legacy. Your heir inherits the gold collected on your previous runs and can use it to upgrade Castle Components for new classes and permanent benefits
helpfulPercent: Forge New Weapons and Armor with statistical upgrades and powers and Enchant Runes that slot into each piece of equipment which grant you important skills to customize your character to your play style. All these upgrades carry forward to each heir in succession
votesHelpful: slowly growing your legacy and power and allowing you to more quickly dispatch enemies and make more and more progress.\n\nHumorous randomly assigned Traits (some cosmetic
votesTotal: some debilitating
votesFunny: some extremely beneficial) keep things fresh and endearingly hilarious on each run. This allows you to stay invested until your skills are good enough that the challenge of the level matches your understanding of the system and you to begin to use strategy to plan our your next assault choosing the hero with the class
commentsCount: traits or spells that would best suit your next run's goals.\n\nSecret Areas
column16: Chests and Skill Based Challenges make each new room of the castle an intriguing surprise as you hope for another armor blueprint
column17: magic rune
column18: or pile of gold that will allow you to purchase more upgrades and finally defeat that next ridiculous boss that has haunted you for generations.\n\nThe game's nostalgia value
column19: smooth
column20: simple controls and delightful humor draw you in
column21: and it's upgrade and advancement system keeps you eagerly playing. The game overall is an impressive
column22: innovative and rewarding title and aside from the difficulty
column23: there is little not to like about this incredible indie game."

In a world where Castlevania went God of War and lost its identity, Rogue Legacy rescues orphanized Castlevania fans. Sure, it doesn't feel exactly like Castlevania, and it shouldn't. It feels like Rogue Legacy, and that's saying a lot.

The many generations of a same family endlessly battling against a castle.
Each generation brings a different, unique character. You can play as many different classes, which can be upgraded. You want to be a Barbarian King/Queen? You can. You want to be a Hokage? You can. You want to be a Lich King? You can.

Seriously, this game is beast. Just buy it. Just. Buy. It.

In theory this game should be good for short sessions of play, but it has a tendancy to pull you in with the idea of just one more run"."

Having been a fan of the rogue-like genre for most of my life as well as hardcore platformers, Rogue Legacy tickled a sweet spot in me that kept me entertained for several hours. It's unique legacy system keeps things interesting on every play through by switching out character traits every time you die and I found myself wanting to try the different classes to see how drastically different their play style would be. To be fair the game has a few short comings, but many can be overlooked due to the fact that it's just enjoyable to play and amass a small fortune only to die and start fresh. Don't take my word on it though, boot it up for yourself and see how your legacy will play out.

Overview:
GET. THIS. GAME. ♥♥♥♥ING. RIGHT. NOW.

Details:
Graphics 5/5 (for not diverging from its late-90s RPG-style)

Gameplay 5/5 (it is extremely simple and enjoyable)

Lasting Appeal 5/5 (more on that down there)

Review:
This game is an awesome Roguelike hybrid. It is a bubbling cauldron of 2-D action platformer, Roguelike, and tower defense. AND IT'S STILL GREAT! When you die (WHEN you die), you upgrade various slots on your Mansion with the gold you earned going through Castle Hamson to better various skills and attain new abilities. Then (the most interesting, unexpected, and well-blended feature I've ever seen in a Roguelike video game) you choose one of three heirs to go through the castle again, with the new skills/abilities/equipment/runes you got with the previous character[s].

This game is a STEAL at $15. Get it now.

So addictive! Death after death, I can't wait to plunge deep into the shifting castle rooms again. Challenging, but not unfair. The trait system is a clever, funny, and engaging twist. Highly recommend this game.

The legacy feature and the trait system is what makes this game unique from today's nostalgia nut stuff. Every person has their own traits that affect gameplay. too fat to fit in the secret door? BAM SHABLAM dwarfism for the win. when yoou die, you die. choose your favorite child to carry on your legacy and while you're at it, upgrade your mansion to affect how well you do when in the castle.

I figured Rogue Legacy would be a solid homage to the Metroidvania genre with a nice, difficult twist, but it goes so much further than that. With its compelling progression and customization systems and an excellent use of randomization, Rogue Legacy is a clear and definitive step forward for the genre.

Any action-platformer game hinges on the player developing a set of reproducible skills -- learning how to read a room, confront enemies and chart a path through treacherous territory. Later Metroidvania games like Aria of Sorrow and Other M shied away from this and instead emphasized character empowerment and customization to the point where base skills like dodging and timing became almost unnecessary. Rogue Legacy deftly solves this problem by randomizing every room on each playthrough while also forcing the player to accept a unique set of strengths and weaknesses on each play session thanks to the game's hereditary system. After a couple hours, the player starts to understand the logic of the game: how each region works, where the greatest challenges are, how to chart a path through the castle and how to compensate for unexpected adversity. It's a brilliant example of a game that teaches the player a difficult and complex system at a steady pace over dozens of hours of play.

If you're a fan of Metroidvania games or a fan of challenging action-platformer games, you're more than likely going to get your money's worth out of Rogue Legacy. But if you appreciate dissecting and understanding great game design, Rogue Legacy is absolutely essential.
This game has a learning curve. If you can climb it, prepare to enjoy a truckload of addictive, unadulterated, joyful old-school hardcore platforming. Seriously, this game is a lot of FUN.

The deal with Charon makes it more imperitive that you get enough money for an upgrade and spending most of your money before going in feels like a success. The bosses provide a good challenge and are well crafted. The monsters of the game are pretty unique and all offer their own challenge by themselves and together. The story is intriguing if rather short, but it was a fun little background to the mayhem. Overall a great little game to spend a good hour in before sccumbing to a stray shot of bloot from a squint.

This is a 2D side scrolling RPG game. Your character uses swords and spells to explore a castle and defeat many enemies along the way. The death element is probably one of the most unique mechanics I have ever seen in a video game. When you die, you get to choose from 3 different children classes, some children may have certain traits to make them better or worse, for example, one child can have vertigo which can turn the screen upside-down and another may have a trait that makes them stronger, it is all random!\n\nAlso there is extensive skill tree system and randomly generated castle that changes everytime you die. You will send your children's children to die over and over and have many many hours of play time, plus with the inclusion of new game plus which makes the enemies even harder then on your last play through makes this game a great challenge. You will die in frustration a lot but you will also have a great sense of satisfaction when you kill that boss for has been killing you over and over again. I recommend this game if you like a challenge and older 2D side scrollers.

TL;DR: Fun, challenging roguelike platformer that'll take you a solid 20-30 hours of playtime to fully complete.

Things I Wish I'd Known
To anyone thinking of getting the game and just starting out, a few recommendations. First, a controller is almost mandatory for this game. There's no mouse support, and while you can use two hands on a keyboard, it feels pretty awkward (and this game involves a lot of twitch reflexes and precision jumping). Also, there's an option to just press down to perform down attacks in the air or fall off platforms (I forget the name, but it should be obvious in the options menu) that's very helpful. And finally, try not to spend an excessive amount of time on the grind - if it's getting repetitive, clear through the bosses and attempt the next game mode. The Steam achievements for this game are actually a good balance of difficult but not impossible
date: and getting all of them should indicate that you're essentially done" with the game. You'll likely get 20-30 hours out of this game before getting that feeling of " why did I just waste all my time on that? " but if you enjoy a challenge and find it at a good price
recommended:
it's definitely worth a look.

Regular Review-y Part
Rogue Legacy is an excellent roguelike platformer with a clever continuity mechanic. Gold and items collected during dungeon attempts can be used to provide static stat bonuses for future attempts
hoursPlayed: allowing the player to shore up their weak spots and fueling the game's progression system. The different classes and powers (via glyphs) provide enough variety to keep subsequent dungeon runs varied and interesting.\n\nThe game can be punishing at first
helpfulPercent: as it allows the player to see the effects of their stat purchases and armor upgrades
votesHelpful: as well as their improving play. Rogue Legacy is a game that encourages player mastery - better play will lead to greater completion of the dungeon and more gold to spend for the next round. And just when you've gotten good enough to clear the dungeon and defeat all the bosses
votesTotal: the game will ramp up the difficulty with a "New Game +" mode. The new mode allows you to keep all your progress
votesFunny: but is balanced well enough that the previously easy intro part of the dungeon is now challenging again. The game also includes five "hidden" bosses
commentsCount: which are far more challenging versions of the standard bosses. These can be taken on at any time (your purchased stat bonuses don't affect the stats of the avatar during these challenges)
column16: but they provide a sort of endgame for players who have found the rest of the dungeon too repetitive. That said
column17: I'd recommend looking up the slightly gamey strategy for defeating Alexander IV
column18: as the "normal" strategy will lead to an absurdly challenging and probably frustrating fight.\n\nThe game isn't without its downsides. The grind can feel a little repetitive at times
column19: and there could be more indication that defeating the bosses on the first run through isn't the end of the game (as it is
column20: it's confusing that by the time you're able to tackle the bosses in the first playthrough you've barely bought into the stats
column21: and you won't have found all the armors). Not helping the repetitiveness is the music. It's not bad
column22: at first
column23: but after a few hours you'll want to turn on something else with more variety. But in the end
column24: those are two relatively minor downsides in an otherwise great game."

reviewText: An excellent Castlevania-style platformer with roguelike elements. Because gold and upgrades carry over between characters, permadeath doesn't make you feel like your run was wasted when you eventually miss a jump and fall onto a bed of spikes. Combat is fairly simple, but pleasantly fast-paced, and the assorted challenge rooms, random positive and negative perks, and various other nuances make repeated trips into the castle very entertaining. I do wish there was a bit more enemy variety (there's a fair number of palette swaps), and some of the rooms show up more often than I'd like, but overall Rogue Legacy is definitely worth a look for platformer fans and roguelike fans alike.

Rogue Legacy is an amazing platformer.  Controls are tight, tons of loot, a vast array of baddies, and a lot of customization options.

However, there isn't much of a story.  Boss battles are fun, but can be quite challenging.  That's good though, as you can get many hours out of this title because of it's challenge and replay value.  There are a good deal of characters you can pick from, each with their own abilities.  It should be noted, however, that each character usually also has a querk, too.  For instance, some characters play the game up-side-down.  Others are color-blind.  Some have flatulence issues.

So, I HIGHLY reccamend Rogue Legacy.  It's a terrifically fun platformer, which has a great soundtrack, and boasts hours of play time.
Very heavily inspired by Castlevania: Symphony of the Night with a few roguelike elements added to it. A bit on the easy side, but still a lot of fun.

Great 2d platformer with a random roguelike castle system, gameplay in the vein of castlevania to be enjoyed with a controller.

The roguelike and heritage system fits perfectly in the hard to master play style where you are bound to die often, by dieing you get to buy and spend your loot to come back again to a new generated castle with your more powerful heir. The traits mechanics add a fun twist and a lot of variety to the basic concept of 2d platform fighting.

Is real easy to get into it and has a quick return which sets it apart from other games of the genre that usually have to be mastered before getting a real enjoyment out of it.
For those who like to be punished, this game is for you.  Massive replayability.

What if Castlevania: Symphony of the Night and a roguelike had a baby? Well, that baby would be monstrous, but its name would be none other than Rogue Legacy. In RL, you attempt to trudge through a randomly generated castle, collecting as much money as possible, beating back baddies, gathering up blueprints and runes, and hopefully taking out a boss or two.  The goal is to take out the four main bosses from the five different areas of the castle, then proceed to the main antechamber where you’ll fight the final bosses.

Of course, you won’t survive. Neither will your child. Or your children’s children. And so on. What gives? Well see, the only way you improve is by spending money outside the castle to build up your fort and buy new equipment and runes…but once you enter the castle, you don’t leave.  Your children will take your place when you die, first starting at the fort to build stuff up, then arriving at the castle to start the journey over again anew.

With all the ridiculous classes, traits, skills, equipment, and all the rest, the game constantly presents itself as an original challenge each time and is addictive as hell. If you like roguelikes, SotN, or both, you owe it to yourself to pick this up.

I just keep coming back to this game.  Rogue Legacy is a game that can be enjoyed in small pieces but it takes a long time to master.  I love getting a little bit better every time I play.  The basic mechanic is that every time you die you start over as a new character, but any upgrades you've purchased persist.  I still have only beaten the first two bosses after 26 hours, but the randomly generated dungeons have stayed fresh and interesting.  I definitely recommend this game.

When you think of roguelikes, you normally think of randomness, high difficulty, and most importantly, permadeath. Dying in those games is very serious, you lose everything: Characters, stats, items, all gone. In that genre, death really means Game Over. But what if it didn’t have to be that way? Enter Rogue Legacy.

You are a warrior tasked with exploring a magical castle and defeating monsters within, with Castlevania-like gameplay that should be familiar to everyone. The twist is that, when you die, that character is gone, and you start playing as one of their heirs, with different traits and classes. The money and treasure gathered by the deceased are passed on, and you can spend them on upgrades and equipments for the new generations.

The game manages to keep a constant sense of progress with the upgrade system; dying is not the end, it’s the beginning of a new adventure where you’re likely to be better prepared. It’s not just about getting better stats and armor, either, you’ll also unlock new classes and mechanical improvements, like dashes and air jumps.

Your descendants are, however, randomly generated. This goes for both class and traits, the latter of which are characteristics like Glaucoma" or "Dwarfism" that can be very helpful
recommended: or highly crippling. The unreliability inherent to the heirs often forces you to adapt to something that "will do" instead of having the best for the task available
hoursPlayed: which makes victory all the more sweet.\n\nAnd of course

reviewText: In a nutshell: Roguelike-lite Metroidvania with upgrades. I was hooked once I played the demo, and the full game is significantly more awesome and fleshed-out. Difficulty is good, maybe a little on the hard side if you're rusty on action platformers (like me). The game is genuninely funny, too. It's hard not to grin when Pricila IX, a nearsighted, bald assassin, goes charging into battle with her massive sword lifted above the tiny pink bow on her helmet.\n\nEdit: New Game+ increases the difficulty sharply. This Rogue-Lite (death costs money, but stats and equips are kept) offers Castlevania SotN play and controls with an ever changing castle/dungeon system. Several different character types allow for different play-styles and advantages in certain situations and against some enemies. The enemies scale with you and, though your stat, equip, and gamer skills improve, you will notice the enemies do not have to be one-hit kills if you do not want them to be. The bosses add a level of strategy and pattern memorization which is exciting the first time through; however, certain hidden bosses require more than a little luck.\n\nOverall, I found this to be a very fun SotN tribute and the progression kept me hooked for hundreds of generations. Enjoy!

The genre of this one is RPG roguelike 2d platformer. I have seen so many reviews of people comparing this to the Binding of Issac. ♥♥♥♥ those reviews, this is nothing like that game. The only thing they have in common is that each run is different.

In Rogue Legacy, you are basically running around in a castle collecting as much money as you can (for your legacy) and killing monsters (for yourself). Each time you enter the castle, it is different inside. Once dead, you must choose a new heir (1 of 3) to explore the castle. Everyone is different. Everyone has a unique name, a class, a gender, and random attributes that make them unique. The money you earn goes to that heir and is used for purchases of items/upgrades/unlocks and must be used before going into the castle. What you choose to purchase stays for every character (equipable items can be switched/unequipped). Everyone gets 1 life to live. There are some small exceptions to things I've mentioned, but that's via unlocks anyway.
Loads of content and even when you complete the game, you STILL have more stuff to unlock.

Dont mess with Secret Boss !

This Game is Perfect For rogue-like Pro-gamer

This game is a legend among it's kind. It took me around 44 hours to beat or more but you can rush it in probably about 30. This game can be hard or easy at the same time, offers something new every play-through, and has near-unlimited replay-ability. Bosses are unique and every situation can be approached in different ways depending on your build and your current class. I would definitely suggest this game to literally any kind of player; young or old, casual or hardcore.\n\n5/5 Do I recommend this game Steam asks of me? Yes I do.

reviewText: Awsome.... Just awsome :)

Rogue Legacy is a game that has more content and replayablity than most big budget AAA titles on the market right now. Rogue Legacy is about your decendents as you search Castle Hamson for treasure and other reasons.

You will play as one of three randomly generated characters who will loot a castle and its surrounding areas for gold which you will use to upgrade you manor and level up. Upon death, you can level up your stats and other bonuses, get armor, and choose the next family member to go into the castle.

The controls are perfect and you are the one who feels responsible for screwing up. Even at full price, this game is worth all the money you put in it. Rogue Legacy comes highly recommended, especially if you like randomly generated games.

Pros:
- Simple to adopt, hard to master
- Procedurally generated levels that are perfectly fitting
- Addicting character mechanics (Colour blind, short sighted, etc..)
- Tons of collectibles like weapons and runes to equip
- Beautiful cartoonish artstyle
- Castlevania-ish music!!

Cons:
- Loses difficulty as your character becomes stronger at later stages

Summary:
Imagine a castlevania version of megaman with triple dash or jump, and with perma-death, but with never-ending sons and daughters.

Score:
10/10
Rogue Legacy finds the right balance between grinding and scaling the difficulty level to remain enjoyable for hours of gameplay.  A solid soundtrack is the icing on top!
An amazingly fun game that brings back the feeling of nostalgia and rage enduced violence, at the same time.  Oh, and there's perma-death.

I'll keep this one short; if you enjoy brutal platforming/action element games in the vein of Super Meat Boy, you will probably enjoy this. Unlike SMB, each hero you play with is randomly generated before you start the game. Each hero has their own abilities that will make them useful in some aspect of the game. That being said, the spells you get as a mage will sometimes hurt more than help. Warriors and rogues and whatnot have a better average play ability than a mage. In addition to the different hero types, each hero also has traits randomly selected for them before the game starts. Ever play as a tiny, near-sighted warrior? Again, some of them are good and some are bad. Some will make you puke. The game plays well, and is generally fun, provided you do NOT mind dying every few minutes. But such is a roguelike.

Challenging but rarely frustrating, the randomized dungeons and heroes keep this dungeon delver fresh and fun for a long time. I've been having a blast playing it, learning enemies' attack patterns and tells, figuring out the nuances of each class and how best to utilize them. The soundtrack is great and atmospheric, making an already awesome game AWESOMER.\n\nThe game also has a fun sense of humor, what with some of the purely-for-flavor traits and the general jerkishness of the other humans within the castle. I'd recommend this game to anybody who likes fun.

When you think of roguelikes, you normally think of randomness, high difficulty, and most importantly, permadeath. Dying in those games is very serious, you lose everything: Characters, stats, items, all gone. In that genre, death really means Game Over. But what if it didn’t have to be that way? Enter Rogue Legacy.

You are a warrior tasked with exploring a magical castle and defeating monsters within, with Castlevania-like gameplay that should be familiar to everyone. The twist is that, when you die, that character is gone, and you start playing as one of their heirs, with different traits and classes. The money and treasure gathered by the deceased are passed on, and you can spend them on upgrades and equipments for the new generations.

The game manages to keep a constant sense of progress with the upgrade system; dying is not the end, it’s the beginning of a new adventure where you’re likely to be better prepared. It’s not just about getting better stats and armor, either, you’ll also unlock new classes and mechanical improvements, like dashes and air jumps.

Your descendants are, however, randomly generated. This goes for both class and traits, the latter of which are characteristics like Glaucoma" or "Dwarfism" that can be very helpful

reviewText: AMAZING game.\nRogue Legacy is an interesting hybrid of game concepts; having the random castle generation of a Roguelike, the gameplay style of a Metroidvania, and an RPG-like levelling system.  The game's premise is built around going through successive generations to try to tackle a castle and the evils lurking inside, and with each new generation, you get to choose from among three new characters with randomly-determined character classes and perks.  All of the character classes have their uses (though some, like the Spellsword and Assassin are better" than others)

reviewText:
Combat is a complex mixture of God Of War, Devil May Cry, and the UFC Undisputed games.
Story is at first seems cliche with the character venturing into this mysterious castle hoping to vanquish evil. Turns into a much more complicated tale of psychological horror, political corruption, betrayal, with much more positive themes like cherishing family despite wrong doings and disabilities, and self determination.
Graphics look better than playing Battlefield 4 with ultra settings on a NASA grade hardware.
The music produced by Beethoven and Pink Floyd, so its automatically great.
Crafting and RPG elements are more fun and complicated than raising a child in real life.
23 and a half out of 10. Buy it.

Rogue Legacy has Super Metroid styled Castlevania gameplay with a Dark Souls level of difficulty. The difficulty can disappear as you buy upgrades before you renter the castle, but it will return when you enter new parts of the Castle.  There's isn't much story to it, but then again I stopped reading the journal entries after 7/20 something. Your playable character is on a mission to find the fountain of youth which is hidden inside an enchanted castle. You will need to defeat 4 bosses, 1 from each section of the castle, then a final 2 part boss near the entrance. The final boss door remains locked until the 4 bosses are defeated. When you defeat the final boss you get a credit line you can't skip through, followed by a NEW GAME + mode where the castle's enemies are strengthened, which further ratchets up the difficulty.

Now if none of this didn't sound interesting enough let me highlight some key gameplay features of Rogue Legacy.

- Every time your character dies, he really dies. All of your stats, equipment and gold are transferred to a selectable heir in the next generation. You can choose from 3 possible heirs that will be randomly generated based on what classes you've unlocked. The next generation can have traits that can benefit or hamper gameplay, so from my experience avoid the upside down one at all cost!
- After you choose your heir you can unlock stat bonuses, perks, abilities and classes from this FAMILY TREE menu. If you found gear or runes while in the castle, they are made available to buy outside the castle, but after you unlock the sales people.
- You need to spend as much gold as possible before you renter the castle because there's a demon at the door that takes it all away! This fundamentally will make the game last longer, because you have to perform successful castle runs bringing back enough gold to upgrade or you can't improve the next generation.
- You level up in the game, but it's irrelevant to determine how powerful your character is because your stats don't increase from your LV. All stat increase must be obtained from beating bosses, finding rare chests and slowing buying out the FAMILY TREE. Your level is a marker more for speed runners and hardcore players, like if you can beat the initial playthough of Rouge Legacy before LV 100 you're probably an experienced player. The higher the level the more time and opportunity you've had to buff up your character, which would make the game easy.
- EVERY TIME YOU RENTER THE CASTLE IT RANDOMIZES. The layout of the castle will never be quite the same, or not where you would notice as your grind through heir after heir. This my friend, along with NEW GAME +, is the strength of Rouge Legacy.

The way I see it, this game would be too short if you leveled up too quickly, too boring if the castle stayed the same and too easy if they handed everything to you from the start. They've solved these problems with long grindy gameplay with randomly generated castle rooms, enemies and obstacles. It's an Indie game, so they gave you some room to stretch things out with limited resources. You will find the difficulty to be unbearable at the start, but as long as your bring gold and unlock thing your will gain momentum to do better and better. After you've unlocked everything and have bought everything you will still find value in the many consecutive NEW GAME +s  which seem to have no end.

It makes me wonder what they could do with a better budget without going all Call Of Duty on us. This is my favorite Indie game on Steam. This is supposed to come to PSN in 2014, by then way more people will know about this marvelous never ending game. For sheer fun and coming back for more, wow, it's a great spin on Symphony Of The Night. I can't give it a 5/5 because it lacks a certain gameplay depth I can't explain, it's not complex enough, but it's Indie so what do you expect?

reviewText: In a nutshell: Roguelike-lite Metroidvania with upgrades. I was hooked once I played the demo, and the full game is significantly more awesome and fleshed-out. Difficulty is good, maybe a little on the hard side if you're rusty on action platformers (like me). The game is genuninely funny, too. Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/rogue-legacy-game-review/

Ahh, Rogue Legacy. My favorite rogue-like game, although it also served as my introduction to the genre. Even after playing a lot of others from the genre now, I still look back on Rogue Legacy as my favorite out of the bunch.

The game is presented in a pixel fashion, making use of some nice looking sprites for the various people and enemies you will meet along your journey. This style fits well, especially for a game of this genre. Come to think of it, I don't think I've played a rogue-like that was not in this style, and I've played several of them over the past several months. Can't really complain either, there's nothing wrong with it and I'd actually prefer this style in a rogue-like game, although I may be a bit biased there (heh).

Rogue Legacy's niche is the rebirth mechanic. Upon dying as one character, you'll have the choice as to which of the three offspring of that character you'll play as next. The interesting thing about this mechanic however, is that each child has separate traits, disguised as real world disorders and conditions. These can either be in your favor or against it. ADHD, for example, works in your favor in that your character will move 30% faster than usual. My favorite defect is vertigo, which mirrors the screen vertically. Yes, everything, including menus. Vertigo is a pain to deal with as I cannot rotate my monitor upside down, forcing me to play upside-down.

Aside from that gimmick, the other half of the game is the immense class and upgrade system. You'll start off with no skills, playing as the default class, the knight. Upon death, the opportunity to choose offspring with a different class is presented. The basic classes to choose from contain classes such as: mage, knave, knight, barbarian, shinobi, miner, etc. Each class can be upgraded, getting a name change in the process. The shinobi, for example, changes into the hokage, my favorite class. Each class has its own advantages and disadvantages, keep that in mind.

The shinobi/hokage has the benefit of upgraded strength (175% to be exact), but at the cost of only having 60% HP, 40% MP, and not being able to take advantage of critical hits. I never really used the game's spells, so the MP cut didn't have much of an effect on me, but the HP and critical hits were quite the drawback. Even so, whenever I was given the opportunity to play as a hokage, I always took it. You can't beat 175% damage. I found it crucial to defeating some of the game's bosses. I actually defeated the forest boss (the second one I took on) without getting hit as a hokage, quite the achievement.

On top of the classes, there's also a plethora of upgrades to choose from each time you die. The upgrades are laid out in a branching format, with certain upgrades unlocking others. The first one made available is Smithy, the blacksmith. Once purchased, you'll be able to purchase both armor and weapons from him. There's also an architect (who can keep the last layout of the castle if you choose to not want the game to randomly generate another castle again) and an enchantress, who sells runes, which can be equipped to provide various abilities (like the ability to jump while in air).

The other upgrades consist of class upgrades (like barbarian -> barbarian king) and stat upgrades. This consists of mana, health, and equip upgrades. Equip upgrades allow you to carry more weight and is required if you ever want to wear good armor. There's plenty of other upgrades to base skills (attack up, magic damage up, armor up, etc.) and a few unique ones, like death defy" and "haggle". Death defy
recommended: allows you to defy death (1.5% everytime the upgrade is purchased). Haggle

This is a mashup of Castlevania and a 2D Dark Souls.  There are many rogue like elements, including random dungeon generation, random offspring generation, permadeath, and a high degree of difficulty.  There is of course newgame+ and more so the replayability is way above the 20 hours it took me to beat.  I have no complaints about this game, it deserves to be in your library as one of the best 2D games of this generation.  Seriously, go out and buy it, because it is wildly addictive and a joy to play.

I love games that punish me for not playing perfectly. Things like Super Meat Boy, Spelunky, Super Hexagon, and Limbo are some of my favorites. And when I started Rogue Legacy, it felt like heading back down into the mines of Spelunky. But as I kept playing, that changed a bit. This game is hard on you, but it's not unforgiving because, even when you fail, you make progress.

I hesitate to call this a rogue-like because it moves almost all progression from the game to the meta-game; you don't power up at all (except for one or two rare exceptions) while you're playing, and when you do, it's permanent. Contrast that with Spelunky, FTL, Binding of Isaac, Desktop Dungeon, etc., where failure means a complete restart, and you get a much different experience - a nicer, kinder experience.

This rogueish-like (rogue-likeish? rogue-like-like?) gameplay is perfectly complimented by smooth platforming mechanics, very solid controls (though I would recommend a gamepad), a good variety of enemies, and a great soundtrack. Toss in the descendent and trait gimmicks and this you've got yourself a well-designed, highly replayable, very polished experience.

For me, until now, best game of 2014 (I know that it came out last year).\nIn a few words: a must!!!

Rogue-like gaming meets Castlevania and a persistant upgrade system.  If your curiouse about Rogue and Rogue-like 'hardcore' gaming then this is an excellent place to start.  While it has the harsh and randomness of a Rogue-like. it also has an underlying persistant progression that all of your characters share and benefit from as you unlock it and a rather unique sense of humor.   There are a wealth of classes and features to play around with as you progress through the game and not much is missing in the way of challenge you'd expect from a game in this genre while still managing to be more approachable by newcomers.\n\nThough it does bare mentioning that if you sit there and grind those manor upgrades you'll soon find the challenge stripped from the game, if only for the time being till your progress catches up with your power.  I recommend not grinding, sure grab all the money and pickups you can per run but -do not- grind.  you may find  that stripping the challenge from the game (even temporarilly) may also diminish your enjoyment of it.

reviewText: Be warned that every time you think you are going to stop; you don't.

This game is fun. It combines really punishing platforming, RPG elements, and randomly generating levels to create a rewarding and fast paced game. Also, every time the protagonist dies, you get to play as the hero's daughter or son, and you continue to go down the family tree, each child having some kind of deformity. It's funny, and I always like to play as a midget when I can.

Rogue Legacy does exactly what a roguelike needs to do.  It keeps me coming back for more, even when, occasionally, I left by throwing my laptop out the window.  It can be tough (it gets easier), but victory in games like this are massively rewarding.  The gameplay, story, and artwork are all top notch.  Beyond even that, the feel of the game is excellent.  It is paced so well and stays consistently interesting, and the ebb and flow of hard/easy parts is perfect.  As you upgrade your heroes, enemies get harder, but it is always a great give and take.  Love this game.  First game on steam that I've played until I had every possible badge.

It's good for a quick blast but can't be played forever.\n\n

I figured Rogue Legacy would be a solid homage to the Metroidvania genre with a nice, difficult twist, but it goes so much further than that. With its compelling progression and customization systems and an excellent use of randomization, Rogue Legacy is a clear and definitive step forward for the genre.

Any action-platformer game hinges on the player developing a set of reproducible skills -- learning how to read a room, confront enemies and chart a path through treacherous territory. Later Metroidvania games like Aria of Sorrow and Other M shied away from this and instead emphasized character empowerment and customization to the point where base skills like dodging and timing became almost unnecessary. Rogue Legacy deftly solves this problem by randomizing every room on each playthrough while also forcing the player to accept a unique set of strengths and weaknesses on each play session thanks to the game's hereditary system. After a couple hours, the player starts to understand the logic of the game: how each region works, where the greatest challenges are, how to chart a path through the castle and how to compensate for unexpected adversity. It's a brilliant example of a game that teaches the player a difficult and complex system at a steady pace over dozens of hours of play.

If you're a fan of Metroidvania games or a fan of challenging action-platformer games, you're more than likely going to get your money's worth out of Rogue Legacy. But if you appreciate dissecting and understanding great game design, Rogue Legacy is absolutely essential.

Rogue Legacy is an amazing platformer.  Controls are tight, tons of loot, a vast array of baddies, and a lot of customization options.

However, there isn't much of a story.  Boss battles are fun, but can be quite challenging.  That's good though, as you can get many hours out of this title because of it's challenge and replay value.  There are a good deal of characters you can pick from, each with their own abilities.  It should be noted, however, that each character usually also has a querk, too.  For instance, some characters play the game up-side-down.  Others are color-blind.  Some have flatulence issues.

So, I HIGHLY reccamend Rogue Legacy.  It's a terrifically fun platformer, which has a great soundtrack, and boasts hours of play time.

I just keep coming back to this game.  Rogue Legacy is a game that can be enjoyed in small pieces but it takes a long time to master.  I love getting a little bit better every time I play.  The basic mechanic is that every time you die you start over as a new character, but any upgrades you've purchased persist.  I still have only beaten the first two bosses after 26 hours, but the randomly generated dungeons have stayed fresh and interesting.  I definitely recommend this game.

The game is great, it is quite difficult, and has a lot of custimization and exploration, but that's not what I wanted to talk about. The remix battles are what I meant, these are some of the most gruelingly insane boss fights I've ever seen, in fact it makes me sick to think that human beings programmed these. All they are is just a constant stream of projectiles in every direction, every step you make leads you into something that wants you dead, or every step you don't take. Even if you were invincible it would still be impossible because they are just that hard. It would be easier to lead a horse to water, teach it how to turn into an oven with bright flashing purple wings that kills innocent bananas. Don't play the remix battles if you want to keep your sanity. Clearly it has already had an effect on me, so don't be the next poor soul to driven insane!

It's been a long time since I've been fully addicted to a video game. Rogue Legacy provides the perfect amount of fast-paced gameplay, challenge and variety to be an easy pick in my library. Combat is satisfying and smacks a bit of Metroidvania style. The classes are balanced, the enemies are varied and the bosses can prove fiendishly difficult until a proper strategy has been worked out. The respawn system, in which your character is endowed with traits (some useful, some not so useful) is incredibly creative and sometimes can be downright hilarious. I would highly recommend Rogue Legacy to anyone.

Despite the fact that Scouts and Skeletons (among other enemies) are absolute attention ♥♥♥♥♥s that I often have to keep my eye on (HAHAH Scouts) that I often have a bone to pick with (HAHAH Skeletons), this game is absolute perfection. Beneath its complicated appearance what with the whole lineage thing, this deceptively simple game has me playing for hours on end and I  NEVER GET BORED. As a Roguelike, death is permanent, which sucks if you finally find the perfect child. This aspect keeps you on your toes, making you constantly adapt to the downfalls of each child. Also, the amount of defferent enemies in this game is... well...... MASSIVE. Every time you play, you get forced to immediately remember the strategy to fight each enemy, keeping your mind as active as your fingers as you spam the attack button constantly. If I could rate this game as a part of this review, it would be 11/10. I don't just roguelike it, I rogueLOVE it.

Rogue Legacy. Damn, I love this game. It's so fun. Anyways, Rogue Legacy is a rogue-lite game that requires you to kill 4  bosses in order to open a golden throne room, that I have yet to know what's inside. The game is quite difficult, let me just say that. When you die, your children will succeed you. You pick one child and you use them you hopefull finish the game. Then when you die after, you always have 3 children to choose from. When you die, you don't have to completely restart. You keep all your equipment, and all the points you spent on the manor (your perks such as more health, more mana, attack power up, etc.) So you level up with each point in the manor. Now, the gameplay. You basically can move and jump and slash and cast spells to kill enemies. Pretty simple. You can also have a smithy who has the equipment *note: you must find blueprints for your smithy to be able to make it, then you buy it.* The enchantress can enchant your equipment with runes to give extra bonuses and power ups. *note: you must also find the runes yourself.* There's a lot more to the game, but that's all I can explain now. Verdict: 9/10. BUY THE GAME NOW! FULL PRICE! NOW! THE SECOND YOU READ THIS!

I figured Rogue Legacy would be a solid homage to the Metroidvania genre with a nice, difficult twist, but it goes so much further than that. With its compelling progression and customization systems and an excellent use of randomization, Rogue Legacy is a clear and definitive step forward for the genre.

Any action-platformer game hinges on the player developing a set of reproducible skills -- learning how to read a room, confront enemies and chart a path through treacherous territory. Later Metroidvania games like Aria of Sorrow and Other M shied away from this and instead emphasized character empowerment and customization to the point where base skills like dodging and timing became almost unnecessary. Rogue Legacy deftly solves this problem by randomizing every room on each playthrough while also forcing the player to accept a unique set of strengths and weaknesses on each play session thanks to the game's hereditary system. After a couple hours, the player starts to understand the logic of the game: how each region works, where the greatest challenges are, how to chart a path through the castle and how to compensate for unexpected adversity. It's a brilliant example of a game that teaches the player a difficult and complex system at a steady pace over dozens of hours of play.

If you're a fan of Metroidvania games or a fan of challenging action-platformer games, you're more than likely going to get your money's worth out of Rogue Legacy. But if you appreciate dissecting and understanding great game design, Rogue Legacy is absolutely essential.
This game is really fun, unique and REALLY addicting. From the whole upgrading system, the different traits, and the really fun as well as challenging platforming sections, this game is worth a buy.

I love games that punish me for not playing perfectly. Things like Super Meat Boy, Spelunky, Super Hexagon, and Limbo are some of my favorites. And when I started Rogue Legacy, it felt like heading back down into the mines of Spelunky. But as I kept playing, that changed a bit. This game is hard on you, but it's not unforgiving because, even when you fail, you make progress.

I hesitate to call this a rogue-like because it moves almost all progression from the game to the meta-game; you don't power up at all (except for one or two rare exceptions) while you're playing, and when you do, it's permanent. Contrast that with Spelunky, FTL, Binding of Isaac, Desktop Dungeon, etc., where failure means a complete restart, and you get a much different experience - a nicer, kinder experience.

This rogueish-like (rogue-likeish? rogue-like-like?) gameplay is perfectly complimented by smooth platforming mechanics, very solid controls (though I would recommend a gamepad), a good variety of enemies, and a great soundtrack. Toss in the descendent and trait gimmicks and this you've got yourself a well-designed, highly replayable, very polished experience.

For me, until now, best game of 2014 (I know that it came out last year).\nIn a few words: a must!!!

This innocent little game will always have you hating it, and, coming back for more at the same time. One unique feature is that every time you die, that's it. No respawns, no lives, no second chances. But, fear not! You can select an offspring to continue your journey. Each child will have different characteristics that define them. For example, they might have dwarfism, and be really small, or have vertigo, where you have to play the entire game upside down! Obviously, not all of the traits are good, but they do serve to spice up the game. On top of that, each life, the castle has a new layout, which means you will never have the same map... unless you lock the castle. This is the one feature I didn't like; You can give up a percentage of your gold to lock the castle and keep your progress. It feels like cheating to me. You should have to find all the bosses, not just teleport to them! Despite that, it's a really fun game that will have you hooked. Buy it!

I can’t overstate how great this game is. This might be one of my favorite games of all time. It’s incredibly challenging yet deeply rewarding. You will find yourself dying over and over again yet you are happy to come back for more punishment. The idea of having to pick a character – each with their own strengths and weaknesses – from a randomized gene pool is a great concept. Sometimes you will simply have to concede defeat and sometimes you will luck out and prepare yourself for a long run into unknown worlds. The randomized castles are a great mechanic that provides a fresh experience every time you restart. The ability to unlock power ups and game-changing mechanics is unique and fresh and allows for much more gradual difficulty curve. Eventually you should be able to beat the game; the question is how many hours will it take? It took me just under 20 hours to beat the final boss. The game is hard but not Spelunky hard.

Rogue Legacy is one of those games that perfectly balances the simple with the hectic. The game could be called simple, like many side-scrollers can, but there's a lot worth thinking about and strategic decisions to be made in regard to the upgrade tree for your character. While the various rooms of the castle explored by your hero can be quite chaotic, it's never completely overwhelming. The difficulty level in this game is perfectly balanced for it's play-style (dying a lot but not too much or in a bad way.) The game has great replay-ability as when you beat" the game

It's supported by solid achievements and trading cards. Rogue Legacy is completely enjoyable. It'd be hard to regret purchasing it. I know I never will.

Strongly suggest giving it a try! It really is a great experience."

When you think of roguelikes, you normally think of randomness, high difficulty, and most importantly, permadeath. Dying in those games is very serious, you lose everything: Characters, stats, items, all gone. In that genre, death really means Game Over. But what if it didn’t have to be that way? Enter Rogue Legacy.

You are a warrior tasked with exploring a magical castle and defeating monsters within, with Castlevania-like gameplay that should be familiar to everyone. The twist is that, when you die, that character is gone, and you start playing as one of their heirs, with different traits and classes. The money and treasure gathered by the deceased are passed on, and you can spend them on upgrades and equipments for the new generations.

The game manages to keep a constant sense of progress with the upgrade system; dying is not the end, it’s the beginning of a new adventure where you’re likely to be better prepared. It’s not just about getting better stats and armor, either, you’ll also unlock new classes and mechanical improvements, like dashes and air jumps.

Your descendants are, however, randomly generated. This goes for both class and traits, the latter of which are characteristics like Glaucoma" or "Dwarfism" that can be very helpful
recommended: or highly crippling. The unreliability inherent to the heirs often forces you to adapt to something that "will do" instead of having the best for the task available
hoursPlayed: which makes victory all the more sweet.\n\nAnd of course

reviewText: In a nutshell: Roguelike-lite Metroidvania with upgrades. I was hooked once I played the demo, and the full game is significantly more awesome and fleshed-out. Difficulty is good, maybe a little on the hard side if you're rusty on action platformers (like me). The game is genuninely funny, too. It's hard not to grin when Pricila IX, a nearsighted, bald assassin, goes charging into battle with her massive sword lifted above the tiny pink bow on her helmet.\n\nEdit: New Game+ increases the difficulty sharply. I do NOT recommend finishing your first runthrough in a hurry!

Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/rogue-legacy-game-review/

Ahh, Rogue Legacy. My favorite rogue-like game, although it also served as my introduction to the genre. Even after playing a lot of others from the genre now, I still look back on Rogue Legacy as my favorite out of the bunch.

The game is presented in a pixel fashion, making use of some nice looking sprites for the various people and enemies you will meet along your journey. This style fits well, especially for a game of this genre. Come to think of it, I don't think I've played a rogue-like that was not in this style, and I've played several of them over the past several months. Can't really complain either, there's nothing wrong with it and I'd actually prefer this style in a rogue-like game, although I may be a bit biased there (heh).

Rogue Legacy's niche is the rebirth mechanic. Upon dying as one character, you'll have the choice as to which of the three offspring of that character you'll play as next. The interesting thing about this mechanic however, is that each child has separate traits, disguised as real world disorders and conditions. These can either be in your favor or against it. ADHD, for example, works in your favor in that your character will move 30% faster than usual. My favorite defect is vertigo, which mirrors the screen vertically. Yes, everything, including menus. Vertigo is a pain to deal with as I cannot rotate my monitor upside down, forcing me to play upside-down.

Aside from that gimmick, the other half of the game is the immense class and upgrade system. You'll start off with no skills, playing as the default class, the knight. Upon death, the opportunity to choose offspring with a different class is presented. The basic classes to choose from contain classes such as: mage, knave, knight, barbarian, shinobi, miner, etc. Each class can be upgraded, getting a name change in the process. The shinobi, for example, changes into the hokage, my favorite class. Each class has its own advantages and disadvantages, keep that in mind.

The shinobi/hokage has the benefit of upgraded strength (175% to be exact), but at the cost of only having 60% HP, 40% MP, and not being able to take advantage of critical hits. I never really used the game's spells, so the MP cut didn't have much of an effect on me, but the HP and critical hits were quite the drawback. Even so, whenever I was given the opportunity to play as a hokage, I always took it. You can't beat 175% damage. I found it crucial to defeating some of the game's bosses. I actually defeated the forest boss (the second one I took on) without getting hit as a hokage, quite the achievement.

On top of the classes, there's also a plethora of upgrades to choose from each time you die. The upgrades are laid out in a branching format, with certain upgrades unlocking others. The first one made available is Smithy, the blacksmith. Once purchased, you'll be able to purchase both armor and weapons from him. There's also an architect (who can keep the last layout of the castle if you choose to not want the game to randomly generate another castle again) and an enchantress, who sells runes, which can be equipped to provide various abilities (like the ability to jump while in air).

The other upgrades consist of class upgrades (like barbarian -> barbarian king) and stat upgrades. This consists of mana, health, and equip upgrades. Equip upgrades allow you to carry more weight and is required if you ever want to wear good armor. There's plenty of other upgrades to base skills (attack up, magic damage up, armor up, etc.) and a few unique ones, like death defy" and "haggle". Death defy

I bought this game thinking it would just entertain me for a couple hours since it was on sale for a pretty good deal, but I actually ended up really liking it. Rogue Legacy does a really good job of creating a challenging game, but not making it so challenging to the point where you want to punch your computer screen. It can be hard starting out but once you start clearing out the castle more and beating a boss it feels so rewarding. There are so many diverse classes to choose from that all have a different take on your approach at the castle keeping the game fresh and not just doing the same thing over and over again. It is also very amusing with the different disabilities like IBS or Color blindness. If you would want a platforming beat em up rpg style game then this game would fit your needs very well and I would highly recommend it.

Rogue Legacy is a action RPG roguelike platformer, and if you think that's a weird mix of genes, man, wait until you see your Player Characters!

This game drew me because it's a roguelike - it has randomised challenges to keep things fresh, and the permadeath forces me to stay on my toes, but every challenge it throws at me is beatable. (i.e. harsh, but fair.) However, having finished the game, I can safely add one more bit of praise for it: few other games marry theme with mechanics as well as Rogue Legacy.

Saying more would be a spoiler, but I sincerely hope that this game's legacy goes on for a very long time.

A great interpretation of the Rogue-Lite progression system. Combines challenging combat and character customisation with a classic arcade aesthetic, making it a worthwhile experience for gamers new or old. Rogue Legacy will make you work for its various rewards, but the many hours of dungeon crawling are complemented by a surprisingly excellent OST and the occasional splash of humour. If you're looking to support Indie developers with your time and money, you can't go wrong here.

Rpg, action, platformer, that will make you laugh everynow and then and get you playing for hours without an end, because when it ends, did it really?

reviewText:
Another game oozing with really smart game design, Rogue Legacy is probably what you’d get if you crossed Castlevania with a “bullet hell” game like Ghouls N’ Ghosts. Like Castlevania, the main objective of Rogue Legacy is to explore a castle and defeat several bosses within it.

But what sets Rogue Legacy apart and makes it really fun and interesting is that, when you die - and you will die a lot - you get to choose between 1 of 3 children of the character you were just playing to avenge their parent and explore the castle. Each child may have genetic abnormalities or traits that make the game play differently each time. Some will directly affect gameplay, while others are just for flavor. For example, you may have a child who’s a midget. They’ll have a smaller hitbox and be able to go through small openings, but they may also take more knockback. Or you might have a child who’s colorblind. Then the game is played in black and white until you die again. And each time you die, the layout of the castle is randomly rearranged, so it’s kind of like playing a brand new game each time. You’re also free to swap out skills and equipment to experiment with different playstyles if you’re stuck on a boss. Really cool stuff. On top of that, you’ll inherit your items from your parent when they die, but the game makes you spend the money you inherit on upgrading new items or skills before you reenter the castle. So each time you die, there’s a kind of moment where you think “Crap I died…But now I get to choose a new character and upgrade their items and skills!” A neat mechanic because it makes you never feel overly frustrated when you die. Which is good, because this game is hard. And you’ll die. A lot.

I can’t really think of too many negative criticisms of this game, it’s very solid and well designed. Again, not too pretty to look at, but that doesn’t matter to me for a game like this. Maybe the soundtrack was a bit unremarkable, but that’s nitpicking. Check out Rogue Legacy if you can handle a challenge.

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/
I love this game Even after I beat it, there is so much more to do on it. This is a must have.

reviewText: An absolutely amazing game. Rogue Legacy delivers on all levels. The music brings back memories of Diablo II. The look of the game is definitely classic Super Nintendo Ghouls and Ghosts, however the gameplay has merit in its own right. It does not really play like Ghosts and Goblins or its successor Ghouls and Ghosts, which is not a bad thing. Many different character classes can be unlocked and each class has its own special ability that takes mana. You will find new pieces of armor and runes as you play, which you can purchase after your character's inevitable permanent death. Upon death you will then choose an heir to keep your legacy alive. Each character has its own special traits that can help or hinder you along the way. The runes that you acquire will give your character new abilities or they can do things such as make enemies harder, but also give you more gold.\n\nRogue Legacy is challenging, it will test your prowess. The game features a new game + mode, which makes it even more difficult and allows you to continue upgrading your manor and purchasing new armor and runes even after you have completed the game. The short storyline is good and it will keep you motivated to keep going.

Amazing, difficult, addictive.

This game is one huge pile of anger, hatred and difficulty.
That is if you've just started the game.

As the game progresses, it will stop being hard anymore..... until you unlock New Game+, which will become your worst nightmare (if you rush the game).

The soundtrack, bosses, items, level up system.... simply awesome! :D

In general I enjoyed it. Totally recommending if you're fan of platforming AND difficult games.

After few hours of gameplay all those deaths will start to get repetetive. That can easily be fixed by quitting the game, starting it up the next day and the repetetivness will be gone.
This is indeed a good game.

As a Castlevania-fan I recommend this... Of the 2d Castlevanias that is. The 3d ones can still go to hell.\nThis game is basically a randomized metroidvania. So if that's your thing, you should find your wallet.\n

Great platformer for casual gamers. There is a game mechanic to prevent steady grinding away at it for gradual increase in resources, equipment, etc. where Charon requires you give up all (or, later on, a majority) of your currency to get back into the dungeon for each generation.

This is the type of game where the player must primarily level up their real-life skills with the controller (or keyboard) for more success in the game, only mildly supplemented by in-game powerups that can be earned.

While definitely geared toward a casual game here and there as time permits, the powerups are very diverse with a skill tree, collectible artifacts that unlock purchasable armor or abilities, and boss characters that are near impossible to beat without a very distinct strategy and some luck make this appealing for more hardcore retro-style players.

One thing I would prefer is to have Steam Cloud enabled on here. I've already reinstalled my operating system twice since I started playing this and kicked myself for not making a backup of my save file.

Holy moly this is some crazy hard and really fun game. If you're up to hard and challenging game this is just for you.

Simple combat (basic attack and use of skills which use mana) and movement mechanics, upgradable item (where you have to find blueprints so you can upgrade your equips) upgradable mansion (through money you collect in your runs).

That's the basic (so far), there's not that much I can say as I only played 10 minutes and that was enough to enjoy the game so far.

10/10

I think with over 260 hours of playtime, I can definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes platformers.\nEverything about this game is perfect, from the responsive controls to the visual style, the story and the upgrade system. The game is absolutely fair, it may be a little difficult in the beginning, but you will get the hang of how it works in no time.\nThere is also a story, but, at least for me, it was not the most important part. Just playing for a few hours with randomized characters and dungeons is so much fun. It might get a little repetetive, but only after...like 100+ hours or so. I play this game daily for about an hour and I still don't find it boring. All of the positive opinions you may have heard about this are true. It is definitely worth the price. Buy it now.

Early contender for game of the year. Sensational hodgge-podge of metroidvania and roguelike games, with tight platforming controls for good measure. A sprinkle of well-played humour and it's the easiest recommendation I'll make all year.

Rogue Legacy is a game that has more content and replayablity than most big budget AAA titles on the market right now. Rogue Legacy is about your decendents as you search Castle Hamson for treasure and other reasons.

You will play as one of three randomly generated characters who will loot a castle and its surrounding areas for gold which you will use to upgrade you manor and level up. Upon death, you can level up your stats and other bonuses, get armor, and choose the next family member to go into the castle.

The controls are perfect and you are the one who feels responsible for screwing up. Even at full price, this game is worth all the money you put in it. Rogue Legacy comes highly recommended, especially if you like randomly generated games.

Rogue Legacy is a game that I had a lot of trouble putting down. It's one of the few games I purposely got 100% of the achievements on because it was fun all the way through. It has everything a good old fashioned gamer will enjoy. Randomized maps, progressive leveling and difficulty, a choose-your-own-path to awesomeness, difficult platforming and puzzles, as well as fun boss fights.

This game is truly unique. The character you start with dies. You then choose from one of 3 heirs/decendants. Depending on what you often pick, the following heirs will have similar traits. The traits are important for many reasons that I won't go into - but Rogue Legacy is definitely worth your time.

There's pretty mimimal story-line but what story you do discover is rather well done. You'll find little tables with a book that progresses the 'lore' and I found myself always wanting to find the next one.

There are runes and equipment to unlock and choose from. You can be a life-stealing, life-to-mana converting caster if you want. You can be a brute force vampire. Maybe have extremely high defenses. Or maybe be a melee glass cannon. The best part is, all are viable and all may end up making certain bosses and combat easier. It's your job to find out how to adapt and evolve your lineage.
A solid Hack'n'Slash with quirky RPG elements.

I like rogue-likes, yeah. This game though makes it a tick more addictive than the usual formula. You do not get to choose which class you play and which traits the char has, but you do get to pick one hero out of three random ones at each start of new round. Your goal - defeat the 4 bosses and open the golden gate at the beginnning of the castle. As you explore the castle, there's gold, runes, blue prints & stat points to gather. Once you die, the next char will succeed the old one by carrying over all the items you gathered beforehand. You can upgrade stats and unlock new classes at you mansion, equip new runes on gear that the blacksmith crafted with the blue prints you found. This game does it right. It is difficult, but with every new character it gets a bit easier and suddenly it 'clicks'.\n\nLove this game!

reviewText: 2 bosses are flying heads and 1 is a floating eyball.\nThere are 12 different mage enemies.\nEventhough the devs have the creativity of kindergeadners this is a good game.

A very interesting concept unfortunately ruined my inexperienced design and a reluctance to update by the dev team. Animation is fluid and sound is okay, caveat here that the jump strike that you are forced to use to defeat certain enemies/platform is incredibly wonky and WILL cause you to lose runs.
My main issue is that the game (by design) doesnt force you to clear rooms , this results in some rooms being tuned to be far too hard (with the intention of you skipping them).
The problem herein lies in the fact that once you reach  later zones/new game +   it is simply  more advantageous to skip every enemy and dash for the boss rooms unless you are overlevelled due to repetitive farming.
Thanks to this flaw the game starts breaking apart because the whole concept of collecting gold coins in order to level up and defeat monsters is moot due to bosses only scaling in hp/damage(and not tiers like the normal monsters) and having predictable patterns.

A lot of wasted oppertunity but still fun the first(and second) run if that is your cup of tea, however unlike games like The Binding of Isaac/Risk of Rain/Spelunky it is unlikely that you will get much replayability out of this.

If you are a fan of the side scrolling Castlevania/Metroid games, then you will enjoy this game.  If you are a fan of The Binding of Isaac, then you will enjoy this game.  Every play is a randomly generated castle that features level design and enemies very reminescent of Castlevania: SotN.  The dificulty is pretty descent for people like me who have trouble keeping up with a lot of things going on in game at once, some of the randomly generated rooms can have over a dozen enemies all with projectile attacks.  Also features a WoW esque talent tree that allows you to use the gold you earned on your last play through to increase you characters skills, meaning that you can grind your way to an easier game play experience.  Overall I would give this game 4/5 rating, thoroughly enjoyable.

This game is a legend among it's kind. It took me around 44 hours to beat or more but you can rush it in probably about 30. Rogue Legacy is a game centered around a trait system, where each generation of the player's family has a child, chosen out of a possible three offspring. Each offspring has a different class, different name, gender, and a whole bunch of traits, such as Vertigo, Dwarfism, Dyslexia, and Hypergonadism.

When your character enters the randomly generated castle, they throw away your family's wealth, to risk the ways of the Knight. When your character dies, their heir to the throne will grow up, and train to avenge them. Of course, this relation will be EVEN BETTER than the last, and have more upgrades than the last, allowing them to best their foes. One day.. They will avenge their parents, and conquer the castle!

reviewText: Fought a giant eyeball 30 times. Beating said eyeball was one that made me vocally cheer for myself. I love this game. Soundtrack never gets old - reminds me of Super Ghouls N' Ghosts and the roguelike enemies are always fun. I've been blind, had vertigo, been gay and a lesbian, had dwarfism, and cursed uncontrollably. It's really imaginative and for about $5 bucks you are getting more than your money's worth. Get this game.\n\nIf only we could all be so grossly incandescent.

reviewText: In Rouge Legacy, you have to survive in a castle that you can never get out of. Collect gold on your way. When you beat the game_ it's not over.

My heir, heading into the unknown to save the day. AAANNNNNDDD he is dead.


My heir, heading into the unknown to save the day. AAANNNNNNDDD she is dead.



and so on and so forth.
fun game give it a go :)
It's pretty good

My legacy has gone rogue. My 7-year-old has been playing it and he likes the Knight class so much he doesn't want to upgrade it to the Paladin... which means that he cannot unlock any upgrades and his potentially awe-inspiring castle remains a small fort. Each to their own, I suppose.

Anyway, I enjoyed this game - great for a quick blast, plenty to explore and I felt great about finding the hidden class (at the top of the flagpole). It seems very much designed for an XBox controller, though, so playing on mouse and keyboard was difficult (I had to work out and write down the mappings from XBox controls to keyboard controls, plus the down-attack move to activate platforms is far too difficult on the default settings).

It would be nice to carry over money from previous generations to allow the more casual player to build up a fortune... as it was, I found it increasingly difficult to be able to spend my money on anything useful (but did find that investing in the 'vampire' items and runes helped my character survive for longer to get the money). Also, some guidance on the order to attempt the other levels would be useful too (unless I missed something in the notes). Still, I enjoyed the various classes and weird hero traits, and the game overall.

You will like this if:
You like platformers
You like repetition, and improving your skills bc of said repetition
You can deal with the first 20 mins of the game where it will be annoyingly/stupidly difficult
You're ok w this being a fun, little game (i.e. dont take it too seriously)
You like the idea of PROGRESSION and getting stronger
Really, this is a fun game. I took a chance on it as it was only $3, and now that I have it I know I would've been happy to have spent more. It's challenging but not frustratingly so, and its a nice mindless game without being a dumb hacknslash. Much recommended, so long as you fit into the criteria I posted above.
If I still had a controller I'd still be playing this game. It's a really great take on a platformer.
Dark Souls the Platformer

reviewText: Well, haven't played anything quite like this before and I must say at first I was a bit frustrated. However as other reviewers have stated it does get easier if you can tolerate a little grindage. Using a logitech gamepad on this one similiar to the PS3 controller.. and I must say this game is ultra fun, pretty addictive.. the unlocks do come slowy after many deaths but this only fuels your desire to fight back and become more powerful. Your liniege continues familiy member after family member as you pick and chose your successor with each inherited trait/spell you move on one step closer to dominance. Hack and Slash your way through droves of enemies, avoid traps and enjoy totaly random dungeons. Rogue Legacy at the discounted price right now is a must have! Oh and don't forget to flip off Charon for taking your gold at the gate.

reviewText: Very fun and entertaining rogue-like experience.\nIt isn't much difficult nor easy, an overall well balanced gameplay.
A great rogue-lite which needs skill and patience. Also it's also strangelyaddictive and fun to play.
Addicting and hella hard. Reminds me of old 2D platformers. Unforgiving but you keep coming back.

I don't write reviews often, but this game completely stole my heart. Not only does it take me back to the old retro game style with the NES and SNES, but concept of each run being randomly generated, and the progression of slowly building your stats and taking out rooms that would wipe the floor with you a few characters back keeps you coming back for more. Extremely addicting game with multiple hours of gameplay. Even after completing the first run though, I still feel like there's much more left to do.
